Topic.Title: Can ARM cpus match Intel's Performance/watt ??

Message.Msg: marsavian's response to Calxeda's response to Intel... One of the issues with Seamicro was that it didn't/couldn't embed the Atom CPU into the SoC which added cost, size and power. Hence the move from AMD to add ARM to the seamicro fabric. We are focusing on the CPU but for me the really interesting thing is the fabric (in both the seamicro and Calxeda) servers. The amount of (memory/io) bandwidth these things have is amazing. A 24 nodes (96 cores) cluster, 24x 256GB SSD drives, 4GB Ram per node (96GB in total) burns 150-200 watts underload measured from the wall. Clearly it has to be the right work load. There is a limited market for these things - it's just a question of how big/little. I also think that Intel will find it easy enough to reduce power consumption to blunt part of the argument for these things, but don't forget it's not just about the CPU TDP, it's the memory, chipset, fans and then other things such as switches and external cooling. I'll be honest, I'd like to play with one of these boxes just for techie curiosity, but doubt I could shoehorn one into our workloads:)

Topic.Title: Can ARM cpus match Intel's Performance/watt ??

Message.Msg: 'A 24 nodes (96 cores) cluster, 24x 256GB SSD drives, 4GB Ram per node (96GB in total) burns 150-200 watts underload measured from the wall. Clearly it has to be the right work load.' Not bad specs if true. Still x86 processors will leave it no space in traditional integer based server application environments BUT for floating point applications e.g. HPC/Render Farms I could see a small niche they could exploit. You can design FP apps that simultaneously use all the functional units i.e. reducing the benefits of hyperthreading and need high bandwidth per core so this Calxeda strucure might be ideal for that so non threaded ARM cores good at floating point apps might be ideal for this so perhaps they should be changing the emphasis of the market they are targeting. Sure HPC is only about 10% of the market and they will probably only get about 10% of that at most leaving them with about 1% of the server market but hey I could see that technically working and really they are after PR and validation of concept and it would give them that.

Topic.Title: 4 MORE YEARS OF MISERY AHEAD.

Message.Msg: Your racism is coming through. Very few very skilled high tech jobs exist to provide employment to the mass of people looking for work. Even if every unemployed person had the skills to be programmers, chip designers, system engineers etc there would not be enough jobs to satisfy the supply of people. PH.D jobs in teaching and industry are relatively scarce, i doubt there are 1 million such openings across the entire nation.

Topic.Title: 4 MORE YEARS OF MISERY AHEAD.

Message.Msg: A careful application of capitalism and socialism is the best of both worlds. Pure capitalism is destructive, as it evenutally leads to lawlessness and rule of the strong by all means necessary, pure socialism leads to lifestyles that are unsupportable. Also, humans as a rule are not driven purely by self discovery and self development. The Star Trek NG universe is a good example of meritocracy and socialism spread throughout the the hypothetical federation. People strive to be the best they can, but basic things are provided by the technology at hand. That technology is not a crutch but a tool to drive people to greater heights.

Message.Title: Intel 4G LTE
Message.Msg: A number of Intel people have said that Intel will ship LTE-capabile chips in 2012 and ramping in 2013. I think "shipping" means "product for revenue" when no products have been currently introduced. Are there any events in the next 6 weeks where Intel would introduce this kind of product? I thought they would target CES Jan. 8-11, 2013 or Barcelona in early Feb. 23-28, 2013. 2013 International CES, January 8 - 11 Northern Voices Online (blog) quote New Mobile Chips from Intel Early this year, Intel made its formal entry into mobile chipset making sphere. Competing with ARM, the world’s leading computer chipmaker launched mobile chips like Intel Z2460 that you can see inside Motorola Razr I. The company may follow up this chip with dual-core Z2580 at CES 2013, say analysts. The new chip may support 4G LTE and other advanced features. “ARM-based chips, while found in major money makers like the iPad and various Android tablets, aren’t terribly up to snuff when it comes to processing prowess,” says TechRadar. Well, Intel wants to take advantage of this loophole to become a major player in mobile chip business. Indeed, the company may try for valuable partnerships with companies like Apple or Microsoft to make its mobile chips a gain momentum in the growing smartphone and tablet market. 11/14/12 4:00 PM ET UBS Global Technology ConferenceSpeaker: Kirk Skaugen, Vice President, General Manager, PC Client Group "TechCrunch writes that Intel product marketing director Sumeet Syal said that the current Medfield generation does not support LTE at this time, but first LTE-capable chips would be shipping this year and ramping up in 2013."

Topic.Title: Intel 4G LTE

Message.Msg: CES or MWC in Q1 2013 would be a common time to launch...
